EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY ACTION POLICIES



Blythe Energy, LLC maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The EAP will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.



Blythe Energy, LLC employees conduct ongoing inspections, testing, and replacement of the critical items in the ammonia system and the Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system.  Both systems are inspected on a daily basis.  A record of the maintenance or work performed on the systems is maintained electronically on-site.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Blythe Energy, LLC facility is located at 385 N. Buck Blvd., in Blythe, California which is approximately 0.6 miles north of Interstate 10 and 1.5 miles west of California Highway 78.  The area surrounding the Blythe Energy, LLC facility is rural with few commercial businesses surrounding the facility.



The regulated substances of concern at the Blythe Energy, LLC facility are anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia (29%).  Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in a closed loop refrigeration system that chills the air intake of the combustion turbine electrical generators, thereby increasing their efficiency.  Aqueous ammonia (29%) is used in the SCR DeNOx system to reduce the NOx emission in the exhaust gas stream.  The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia and 29% aqueous ammonia are 116,000 pounds (16,000 gallons) and 54,975 pounds, respectively.



Ammonia System:



The ammonia system uses a maximum of 54,975 pounds of ammonia.  The system cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liq

uid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the air intake of a combustion turbine electrical generator.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 65 psig on the low-pressure side of the system to 180 psig on the high side. 



The Compressors and Condensers cycle on and off to comply with system demand during operation.  The ammonia refrigeration system provides cooling for the air intake of a combustion turbine electrical generator.  The system is located primarily in the Engine Room.  The Evaporative Condensers and Relief Valve Water Tank are located outside the Engine Room. 



The process begins with high pressure liquid ammonia draining from the Condensers to the SOC Receiver.  The SOC Receiver maintains a liquid reservoir for oil cooling of the Screw Compressors (5) via a modulating control valve on the outlet to the Flash Receiver.  The control valve is connected to the liquid level in the vessel, and allows excess liquid to flow to the Flash Receiver, at which point the pressure of the liquid ammonia is partially decreased.  The ammonia vapor produced by this partial drop in pressure is drawn from the receiver through the economizer suction port of the Compressors.  Liquid ammonia is fed from the Flash Receiver to the Pump Receiver package.



The Pump Receiver uses five pumps to transfer the liquid ammonia to the Combustion Turbine Inlet Chilling System.  Two pumps feed each of the two Chillers, while the fifth pump is reserved for back-up purposes.  At the Chillers, liquid ammonia partially boils as it absorbs heat from the air intake of the combustion turbine.  The resultant liquid/vapor mix returns to the Pump Receiver where liquid drops to the bottom of the vessel and the Compressors pull suction from the top.



The energy input to the system is supplied by five Compressors.  Each Compressor draws main suction from the Pump Receiver and eco

nomizer suction from the Flash Receiver.  As the name suggests, the purpose for using economizer suction is to increase the efficiency of the Compressors, thereby reducing their cost of operation.  Liquid injection oil cooling is provided by the SOC Receiver, and all Compressors discharge high pressure vapor to the Condensers which are located outside the Equipment Room.  The Condensers convert the high pressure discharge to liquid by spraying water and fan-blowing air over coils filled with the ammonia vapor.  The resulting high pressure ammonia liquid drains to the SOC Receiver to begin the cycle again.



All process equipment and piping are designed according to ASME standards.  All ASME vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves which are set at 300 psig except for the five pumps, which are set at 150 psig.



Aqueous Ammonia (29.5%) SCR DeNOx System:



Liquid (aqueous) ammonia is delivered by truck to the facility, and is stored in a 16,000 gallon tank to the west of the most southern heat recovery steam generator (HRSG).  The aqueous ammonia is pumped from the bulk storage tank via underground piping to a vaporous ammonia delivery skid mounted at ground level in the power block.  The skid contains three flow circuits for the mixing of hot flue gas, aqueous ammonia, and compressed air.  A vaporizer is located at the confluence of the three flow circuits. On-skid piping includes a duplex "Y"-strainer, a flow control valve, and a block valve.  Manual drains and valves are also available.  Normal flow of the aqueous ammonia is through the Y-strainer, flow control valve, block valve and into a spray nozzle located in the top of the vaporizer where it is vaporized and diluted by the hot flue gas. The vaporized ammonia is then distributed to each of the heat recovery steam generators (HRSGs), to remove NOx (oxides of nitrogen) in the exhaust gas stream.



All process equipment and piping are designed according to ASME standards.  All ASME vessels are equippe

d with pressure relief valves which are set at 50 psig except for the five pumps, which are set at 125 psig.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Blythe Energy, LLC ammonia refrigeration system and Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system have many safety features.  Much of the safety of the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the systems.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with EPA Risk Management Program (RMP), Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation, and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  These prevention programs cover those processes that handle anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia (29%) above the threshold quantity.



In addition to the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, in particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."  The facility is manned 24 hours per day, seven days per week.  Operators visually inspect the system twice a day.



Ammonia Refrigeration System:



It is important to note that the ammonia system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The system also incorporates a pressure relief line.  In the event of over-pressurization, vessels will vent through pressure relief valves to a common header which relieves to an outside refrigerant diffusion tank (Relief Valve Water Tank) until the system pressure decreases sufficiently to reseat the valves.  This me

chanism prevents vessels from rupturing in case they become over pressurized



Ammonia detectors are strategically located in the Engine Room, in the inlet to the turbine, in the relief vent line to the Relief Valve Water Tank, and in the vicinity of the chiller coils.  The ammonia leak detectors installed in the Engine Room and those located in the vicinity of the chiller coils will initiate the appropriate actions based on the following concentrations:



-  25 ppm:    Activates the local alarm in the Control Room, the emergency ventilation fan, and the exhaust treatment water pump.  Alarms are activated throughout the facility.

-  250 ppm:  Compressors shut down.

-  20,000 ppm:  Emergency Mode will de-energize all electrical equipment in the Engine Room (with the exception of the emergency ventilation fan and exhaust water treatment) thereby eliminating the potential for an explosion.



The ammonia detector located in the inlet to the turbine will activate the audible and visual alarm at 25 ppm to notify operators of a leak in the Chiller and shut down compressors after 30 seconds at 250 ppm.  The sensor located in the relief vent will trigger an alarm at 0.5% to 1.0% (5,000 ppm to 10,000 ppm) to notify operators that a relief valve has vented.



There are also five Emergency "Kill" switches which can be activated to shut off the electrical power, start the emergency ventilation, and shut down the emergency compressor pump.  Three switches are located outside next to each entry/exit door of the Engine Room, one in the Chiller Control Room, and one in the main Control Room.



In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations would automatically shut-down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut-down, condenser fans and water pumps shut-down, etc.).  Once power is restored, the anhydrous ammonia system can be restarted from the Control Room.



In addition to the 1997 Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Insti

tute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, in particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, AA?Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems.AA?  The facility is manned 24 hours per day, seven days per week.  Operators visually inspect the system twice a day.



Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx System:



The Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system at Blythe Energy, LLC is governed by many safety features.  Much of the safety of the process is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the process.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and the EPA's Risk Management Program (Level 2).  



The 29% aqueous ammonia is stored in a 16,138 gallon double walled tank (Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank) inside a concrete berm containment area located outdoors.  Along with the Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank, the pump skid is also situated inside the concrete containment berm.  The Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is equipped with a vacuum breaker to bring the vessel pressure to ambient pressure.  The Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is also equipped with a single pressure relief valve to prevent the Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank from rupturing in case it becomes over pressurized.



There are "low level", high NOx level, and ammonia slip alarms which alert operators in the Control Room of system mishaps.  A low level alarm is activated when the tank level is at 30% and a message is displayed on the Alarm Sequence Display screen in the Control Room to alert operator to order more aqueous ammonia.  The feed pumps are shut down at approximately 10% and the low level alarm is activated in the Control Room.  A high NOx level will trigger an alarm in the Control Room to alert the operator of a high NOx level at the stack output.  The ammonia slip alarm alerts operators in the Control Room of a high ammonia concentration at the stack output.  



The Emergency Stop button is located near th

e Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank.  Activating the Emergency Stop button would shut down the feed pumps.  The feed pumps can also be shut down remotely from the Control Room.  The Emergency Stop button is activated if the SCR inlet temperature, hot flue gas flow rate, hot flue gas pressure, vaporizer outlet temperature or atomizing air pressure drops below normal operating levels.



The system is also equipped with two leak detectors located underground, one for each SCR skid.  The ammonia detectors will alert operators of an ammonia leak.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Anhydrous Ammonia System:



An investigation into the accident history of the facility revealed that there had been no reportable releases of ammonia over the past five years (July 2005 to July 2010) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds of ammonia or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.



Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx System:



An investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the Hazard Review Revalidation (May 14, 2012) revealed that there have been no significant releases of ammonia at the facility in the last five years (May 2007 to May 2012) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 1,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (Plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  



1.  save lives;

2.  minimize and avoid injuries;

3.  prote

ct the environment; and

4.  minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the CalARP regulations.  



Blythe Energy, LLC personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the anhydrous ammonia system twice daily and the Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system daily.  In case of ammonia detection, visible and audible alarms will activate at the facility and notify the person who is monitoring the system in the Control Room, who will then initiate the Emergency Action Plan procedures.  It is the policy of Blythe Energy, LLC to evacuate facility personnel upon alarm.  There are annunciators located inside and outside the building (horns, strobes, etc.).  Once the annuciator is triggered, the person in charge in the Control Room will send a dispatch team to perform an odor investigation.  The dispatch team dons respirator masks and carries a handheld ammonia detector prior to entering the Engine Room when the concentration is between 0 ppm - 250 ppm.  If the concentration is greater than 250 ppm or if there is a white cloud, everyone must evacuate from the building.  Facility calls the fire department and the HAZMAT team to respond in the event of an emergency.  Riverside County Fire Department will act as the Emergency Response Team.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Blythe Energy, LLC to evacuate all employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel).



See Blythe Energy, LLC's Environmental Emergency Response/Action Plan for a detailed explanation of the Emergency Actio

n policies and procedures in effect at Blythe Energy, LLC.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Revalidation was conducted on July 22, 2010 to satisfy the five year update requirements.  The team involved in the development of the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study made several procedural/managerial recommendations to improve the safety at the facility.  The 2010 Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation consisted of the following:



-  Review of the PHA Requirements / History (Overview / Training Session)

-  Process Flow Diagram Review / Equipment List Review

-  A detailed review of the recommendations generated from the previous 2003 Process Hazard Analysis study and the 2010 Three-Year Compliance Audit.

-  A detailed review of any changes to the ammonia system since the previous Process Hazard Analysis study (reviewed Management of Change Records).

-  A discussion of any releases of ammonia since the previous 2003 Process Hazard Analysis study (review of Incident Investigation Records).

-  Conducted HAZOP study

-  Completion of Emergency Response, EPA Alert, External Events, and Human Factors Checklists.



The status of the recommendations resulting from the 2003 Process Hazard Analysis and 2010 Three-Year Compliance Audit were reviewed.  Any outstanding recommendations from the 2010 Three-Year Compliance Audit are scheduled to be completed by April 2011.  The outstanding recommendations from the 2003 Process Hazard Analysis study will be consolidated into the 2010 Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation with a scheduled completion date of July 2011.



The Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation mitigation measures include enhancements to the ammonia detection equipment and the improvement of existing safety policies and procedures.  All recommendations resultant from the revalidation study are due to be completed by July 2011.



The Hazard Review Revalidation study was conducted on May 14, 2012 to satisfy the five year upd

ate requirements for the Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system.  The Hazard Review Revalidation study generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety for the Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system at the facility.  The mitigation measures include enhancements to the ammonia detection equipment, maintenance, updating the piping diagrams, and the improvement of existing safety policies and procedures.
